Literature Review:
Ultra-high-energy (UHE) gamma-ray astronomy, defined by the detection of gamma rays with energies exceeding 0.1 PeV, represents a burgeoning field within the broader domain of gamma-ray astronomy. This field has gained significant momentum following the discovery of 12 PeVatrons and the detection of photons surpassing 1 PeV. These findings have profound implications for our understanding of cosmic ray (CR) origins and the mechanisms of particle acceleration in the universe. The detection of UHE gamma rays is facilitated by traditional CR measurement techniques, which have evolved over the past three decades to open this new observational window (Aharonian et al., 2006). 

The absorption of UHE gamma rays by the infrared and cosmic microwave backgrounds imposes a well-defined horizon within our galaxy, limiting the distance over which these photons can travel. This absorption is a critical factor in the study of UHE gamma rays, as it constrains the observable universe and influences the interpretation of detected signals (De Angelis et al., 2013). The interaction of UHE gamma rays with these backgrounds is a key area of research, as it affects the propagation of these photons and the subsequent detection by ground-based observatories (Berezinsky et al., 2006).

The Crab Nebula has emerged as a focal point in UHE gamma-ray astronomy, with emissions detected up to 1 PeV. This iconic supernova remnant is a well-known source of high-energy radiation, and its study provides insights into the processes of particle acceleration and emission mechanisms. The detection of UHE gamma rays from the Crab Nebula suggests the presence of extreme accelerators capable of producing electrons and positrons at these energies (Abeysekara et al., 2019). In the absence of hadronic processes, these emissions may indicate the presence of an extreme accelerator of electrons and positrons, challenging existing models of particle acceleration (Hillas, 1984).

The study of UHE gamma rays is closely linked to the pursuit of understanding the origin of cosmic rays, particularly around the knee of the spectrum. The knee, a feature in the cosmic ray energy spectrum, marks a transition in the dominant acceleration mechanisms and source populations. UHE gamma-ray observations can help identify hadronic sources, as these photons are often produced in interactions involving protons and heavier nuclei (Aharonian et al., 2002). The detection of UHE gamma rays from known TeV sources supports the hypothesis that these objects are capable of accelerating particles to PeV energies and beyond (Amenomori et al., 2019).

The use of extensive air shower (EAS) detection techniques has broadened the field of view for UHE gamma-ray observations. These techniques, which involve the detection of secondary particles produced when UHE gamma rays interact with the Earth's atmosphere, allow for the measurement of UHE radiation surrounding the sources. EAS arrays, such as the Large High Altitude Air Shower Observatory (LHAASO), have been instrumental in detecting UHE gamma rays and probing the particle propagation inside and outside the accelerators (Bai et al., 2019). The muon content of these showers provides additional information about the primary particles and the nature of the sources (Aartsen et al., 2013).

The detection of UHE gamma rays also has implications for the study of leptonic and hadronic processes in astrophysical sources. In leptonic sources, UHE radiation is in the deep Klein–Nishina regime, where the cross-section for inverse Compton scattering is significantly reduced. This suppression makes it challenging to detect UHE gamma rays from purely leptonic sources, highlighting the importance of hadronic processes in producing these high-energy photons (Blumenthal & Gould, 1970). The identification of hadronic sources is crucial for tracing the origins of cosmic rays and understanding the mechanisms of particle acceleration in the universe (Gabici et al., 2007).

In conclusion, UHE gamma-ray astronomy is a rapidly evolving field that offers new insights into the origins of cosmic rays and the mechanisms of particle acceleration. The detection of UHE gamma rays from sources such as the Crab Nebula and other known TeV emitters underscores the potential of this field to address longstanding questions in astrophysics. The development of advanced detection techniques and the continued study of UHE gamma rays will undoubtedly lead to further discoveries and a deeper understanding of the high-energy universe.
